comments.author: Cyin Wong

comments.text:
The problem is that we're nowhere near a room-temperature superconductor 
(and it may or may not even be possible), so we're stuck with ordinary 
magnetic repulsion, which isn't nearly as stable and awesome. With two 
regular magnets, you have to perfectly line them up to make 'em float. 
Superconductors work like magic, as you can see in the video, and you could 
just have a line of electromagnets as your "track" turned on in very quick 
succession with no moving parts getting you moving at incredible speeds.

I just read a story a few months ago by Greg Egan called "Zero for Conduct" 
(soon to be collected in *The Best Science Fiction and Fantasy of the Year 
– Volume 8*) where this Afghani high school girl in Iran develops the first 
room-temperature superconductor.
comments.author: Eyedunno
